content.description: Small holds to jugs about 10' up to left facing flake. Lie back to ledge and 1' wide dihedral about 10' up to pine tree. Move left and up to next ledge. 5.8 goes to left up steep blocky dihedral or 5.10+ straight up the middle. Also known as Whaleback Crack in Holzman's book and S.O.B. The start is a little harder since a flake broke off in 2011.
content.protection: 2 hangars on top, 2' and 3' from edge
content.location: 30' right of Pizza route. Start just right of where 1' square flake is missing and 10' left of a bolt.

content.description: Make techy moves through the beginning seam past a bolt.  There is a second bolt on a bulge, and after that easy climbing through some cracks where you might place some gear will lead you to a thin face with two bolts.  Climb onto a ledge after the face, and hope you're tall enough to clip the 4th bolt. Pulling up over the 4th bolt is fun too.
content.protection: There are bolts, but you'll likely want to supplement with small to medium gear. No anchor.
content.location: This route starts on the right, vertical seam of a pair of thin seams that form a "V", close to where the approach trail meets the cliff.

content.description: Great juggy climb on the center of Main Wall. Doesn't protect very well, but can be set up as a top rope from the top access trail. Has some really fun moves.
content.protection: Some nuts and cams if you can find a place for them, bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: To the right of table rock, Pizza is the flake that heads up the wall diagonally to the right.

content.description: A short but high quality crack.  Work up and right to gain the attractive finger crack.  Then head up the crack and traverse slightly left to the tree.
content.protection:
finger size cams and wires for the crux section, hand sized gear for the start 

  There is a fixed piton of unknown quality after the business.  There are other protection opportunities in the area.
content.location: In between Iodine and Mercury up on the ledge

content.description: A fun spicy route that climbs past 3 bolts.  There is a substantial gap between the 1st and 2nd bolt that would likely result in a ground fall if you're just clipping bolts.  A couple marginal small cams can be placed behind a flake after the first bolt that substantially minimize the pucker factor.  The 11ish crux is well protected after the second bolt.
content.protection: Bolts, bring a .5 cam if you're smart
content.location: This is the last bolted route on the upper tier.

content.description: A fun route on the upper tier with some good finger to hand jamming.  Traverse into the crack from the left, head up the crack to a fixed pin, and then traverse out left to a couple old pins.  The crux is low on the route but the pump may get some people.  The bolts and fixed piton are easy to supplement with good gear.
content.protection: mixed, a couple bolts and a fixed pin
content.location: The second route from the left on the upper tier

content.protection: hangars over the top face shared with Beginner's Crack
content.location: Start on the face just left of Beginner's Crack and next to the small overhang.

content.description:
Follow the bolted line to the left of the Pizza Crack. At the second bolt move right to a bulge and follow two more bolts to the top.  

  The anchors of Pizza Crack to the right can be borrowed.
content.protection: 4 Bolts, trad pro to hand width.
content.location: About 10' left of the Pizza Crack.

content.description: Good protection with cams up slabby start. Figure out the fun moves past alcove and roof to top.
content.protection: There are now two bolt hangers over small roof. Note: No rap rings
content.location: Walk past slab to right of beginner's crack and scramble uphill to a slabby face crack

content.description:
Variety of footholds on interesting rock surfaces - (mostly it's not a "friction" slab) - also a variety of smaller and bigger handholds to play with. 

  Go roughly straight up, passing left of a young tree. Reach a nice little platform (about 1 ft by 3 ft) also with convenient handholds - which is 15-20 feet below the top of the cliff. That's the top of the "beginners" route - (trying to climb above it is way harder). 

Variation: Climb directly on the arete at left side of this face (between the "Beginners Crack" corner and the Beginners Face) - looking for the most interesting moves to play with. Crux is at 20-25 feet, stepping over to move up the left side of the arete (around 10c).
content.protection:
Top-rope anchor is a pair of bolts on top of the cliff -- which is 15-20 feet above the little platform at the top of this beginner's route.  

  Most beginners will be safer with a lower directional to prevent them from swinging left across the arete and down into the corner/crack. 

  Note that the obvious way to scramble up around the left end of the wall (to set up the top anchor for top-roping) is slippery and exposed when wet. 

  .(Quality of protection of this route for trad leading is unknown).
content.location: At an eleven-inch-thick tree just right around the corner from "Beginners Crack".Update 8/21: The tree has been cut down, but the stump still remains as a good location indicator.

content.description: Easy, fun slab until the last 15' where you have a tricky face to the same anchors as Beginner's Crack.
content.protection: small cam set if leading. Two anchors over the top.
content.location: just around the cornerto the right of beginner's crack

content.description: Easy enough for kids except the last 10' at the top. Traverse left and roll over the top for the 5.6. If you go straight over the top it feels like 5.8R.
content.protection: Cam set for 1" and smaller cracks and/or nuts. 2 new anchors over the top.
content.location: Left side about 20' from end at a blocky left facing dihedral just right of small overhang.
